name: Tonkatsu/Breaded Pork Cutlet

instructions.description: Take the pork out of the refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking. Season each piece with the salt and pepper on both sides.
Prepare three plates for breading: one with the flour, one with the flour and water mixed, and one with the panko breadcrumbs, and arrange them in that order
Dip each piece of pork in the flour plate, then in the flour-water mixture, and finally in the panko, pressing the meat lightly with your hand to make the panko stick.

In a large frying pan (the pieces of meat must not overlap; cook in two batches if needed), heat 3 cm (1¼ inches) of frying oil to 180°C (355°F). Fry the pork for 2 minutes on one side, turn over, and cook for another 3 minutes, until the meat is nicely golden brown. When the bubbles around the meat become smaller, it means the pork is cooked
Drain on paper towels and leave to rest for 3 minutes before serving with tonkatsu sauce and finely chopped cabbage or coleslaw.

additionalNotes: To replace the tonkatsu sauce: Heat 4 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce, 2 tablespoons ketchup, 1 tablespoon mirin, and ½ teaspoon soy sauce in a small saucepan over low heat and stir until the sauce thickens.

name: Japanese Curry

instructions.description: Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a deep frying pan over medium heat. Add chicken pieces, skin-side down, and cook for 1 minute each side.
Remove chicken. Add remaining oil, onions, garlic, and ginger. Fry until golden and caramelized. Add celery, carrot, and apple, and cook for 10 minutes.
Remove from heat, stir in curry powder, and mix well. Return to heat, add tomatoes and simmer for 2 minutes. Stir in flour, cook for 1-2 minutes, then gradually add dashi or stock.
Add chicken, potatoes, and seasoning (Worcestershire sauce, yeast, soy sauce, salt). Simmer for 20 minutes over medium-low heat.
Cut eggplant into large cubes, zucchini into 1-cm slices, pepper into strips, and trim beans. Fry in 3 cm of oil at 180°C until golden.
Divide rice onto four plates, add curry, and top with fried vegetables.

additionalNotes: To replace the tonkatsu sauce: Heat 4 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce, 2 tablespoons ketchup, 1 tablespoon mirin, and ½ teaspoon soy sauce in a small saucepan over low heat and stir until the sauce thickens.

name: Okonomiyaki/Japanese Pancake

instructions.description: Cut the cabbage into thin strips and scallions into thin rounds.
grate the yam
mix in a bowl the grated yam, water and egss
add the flour and salt and mix.
stir in the cabbage, scalions and katsuobushi (crumbled between your fingers
heat a frying pan and put 1 table spoon oil.

pour a quarter of the batter into the hot pan, cook about 3 minutes. Turn the okonomiyaki over, cover, and cook for 5 minutes. Flip it back and cook, until the bottom is a light golden brown. Repeat the process until all the batter is used

additionalnotes: To replace the tonkatsu sauce: Heat 4 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce, 2 tablespoons ketchup, 1 tablespoon mirin, and ½ teaspoon soy sauce in a small saucepan over low heat and stir until the sauce thickens.

name: Shoyu Ramen

instructions.description: Prepare soup: Combine broth, cha-shu marinade, oyster sauce, and yeast in saucepan. Heat over medium and season with salt.
Cook noodles in boiling water according to package instructions. Drain well.
Divide noodles among 4 bowls. Pour hot soup over noodles.
Add toppings: bean sprouts, halved eggs, pork slices, scallions, and nori.
Sprinkle with pepper and add ra-yu if desired. Serve immediately.

culturalnotes: Tokyo-style shoyu ramen features clear brown broth with soy sauce base. First appeared in 1910 at Asakusa's 'Rairaiken'. The noodles are typically thin and curly.
additionalnotes: For homemade noodles: Use kansui (alkaline water) for authentic texture. Substitute: Thin egg noodles. Save cha-shu marinade for seasoning rice or vegetables.

name: Satsuki's Bento

instructions.description: Prepare all components: cook rice, make chicken karaage, prepare tamagoyaki, and steam vegetables.
Pack warm rice into bento box, pressing gently to form a base. Place umeboshi in center of rice.
Arrange chicken pieces in one section, tamagoyaki slices in another.
Fill remaining spaces with edamame, tomatoes, and broccoli for color balance.
Add nori strips as garnish or make a simple onigiri wrapped with nori.
Let cool completely before closing lid to prevent condensation.

culturalnotes: Japanese bento boxes are carefully arranged meals that balance taste, nutrition, and visual appeal. Mothers often prepare elaborate bento for their children.
additionalnotes: For a Ghibli-inspired touch: Shape rice into characters using molds, or add a mini sausage octopus. Keep food at room temperature if eating within 4 hours.

name: Onigiri

ingredients.name: filling (optional)
ingredients.note: e.g., umeboshi (pickled plum), salmon, tuna mayo, kombu tsukudani

instructions.description: Rinse the rice until water runs clear, then cook in a rice cooker or pot with water.
Let the cooked rice cool slightly until handleable but still warm.
Wet hands with water and rub with a pinch of salt to prevent sticking.
Take a handful of rice, form a dent in the center, and add filling (if using).
Shape into a triangle, ball, or cylinder by gently pressing with palms and fingers.
Wrap with a strip of nori or press nori onto the sides just before eating.

culturalnotes: Onigiri is a staple Japanese comfort food, often homemade or sold in convenience stores. It’s traditionally wrapped with nori separately to keep it crisp.
additionalnotes: For flavor variations: Mix rice with furikake (seasoning), or grill brushed with soy sauce for yaki-onigiri.

name: Yakitori

instructions.description: Skewer chicken and scallions alternately onto bamboo skewers.
Combine soy sauce, mirin, sake, and sugar in a saucepan. Simmer for 5 mins to make tare (glaze).
Grill skewers over medium-high heat, turning frequently, for 5 mins.
Brush with tare glaze and grill 2-3 more mins until caramelized.
Sprinkle with salt (optional) and serve hot.

culturalnotes: Yakitori is a staple of Japanese izakayas (pubs), often paired with beer. Different cuts (e.g., liver, skin) are also popular.
additionalnotes: For extra flavor, add a pinch of shichimi togarashi (Japanese chili blend) before serving.

name: Brown Miso Soup

instructions.description: Peel the vegetable and cut them into bite-sized pieces.
Heat the oil and ginger in a saucepan over medium heat
Add the vegetables and brown for 1 minute
Pour in the dashi and simmer for 5 minutes, until the vegetables are tender
Remove from the heat and mix in the miso

additionalnotes: To replace the tonkatsu sauce: Heat 4 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce, 2 tablespoons ketchup, 1 tablespoon mirin, and ½ teaspoon soy sauce in a small saucepan over low heat and stir until the sauce thickens.

name: Matcha Latte

instructions.description: Sift the matcha powder into a bowl to remove clumps.
Add hot water and whisk vigorously in a 'W' or 'M' motion until frothy (use a bamboo whisk if possible).
Heat or froth the milk (stovetop or steamer) until warm and slightly foamy.
Pour the matcha mixture into a cup, then add the milk. Stir gently if needed.
Sweeten to taste and enjoy hot. For iced, pour over ice after step 3.

culturalnotes: Matcha latte is a modern twist on traditional Japanese tea ceremonies, often enjoyed in cafés worldwide.
additionalnotes: For a creamier texture, use oat or soy milk. Adjust matcha amount for stronger/weaker flavor.
